articles.headline: The Sublime and Scary Future of Cameras With A.I. Brains
articles.snippet: A new generation of cameras like Google’s new Clips device can understand what they see, creating intriguing and sometimes eerie possibilities.
articles.abstract: A new generation of cameras like Google’s new Clips device can understand what they see, creating intriguing and sometimes eerie possibilities.
articles.lead_paragraph: Something strange, scary and sublime is happening to cameras, and it’s going to complicate everything you knew about pictures. Cameras are getting brains.

articles.headline: How Craft Breweries Are Helping to Revive Local Economies
articles.snippet: Across the country, breweries are giving lift to sleepy commercial districts, drawing tourists to once-bustling manufacturing centers.
articles.abstract: Across the country, breweries are giving lift to sleepy commercial districts, drawing tourists to once-bustling manufacturing centers.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIDDLETOWN, N.Y. — As Equilibrium Brewery opened for business here on a recent Saturday morning, fans were already lined up outside for a fresh batch of its hazy-colored ales.

articles.headline: Parkland Massacre Thrusts Guns Into the Midterm Spotlight
articles.snippet: Lawmakers in both parties are recalibrating their positions on gun control in the wake of the massacre at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School.
articles.abstract: Lawmakers in both parties are recalibrating their positions on gun control in the wake of the massacre at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In Minnesota, a Democratic candidate for governor with rural roots is running from his past affiliation with the National Rifle Association. In South Florida, endangered House Republicans are embracing an assault weapons ban.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Alexander Burns

articles.headline: Paychecks Are Getting Bigger. Don’t Get Too Used to It.
articles.snippet: A tight labor market has lifted incomes. But recovering lost ground will require basic changes in economic dynamism and workers’ bargaining power.
articles.abstract: A tight labor market has lifted incomes. But recovering lost ground will require basic changes in economic dynamism and workers’ bargaining power.
articles.lead_paragraph: How low must unemployment go for workers to get a raise?

articles.headline: In Germany’s Car Capital, the Unthinkable: The Right to Ban Cars
articles.snippet: A court ruling has shaken Stuttgart, where it may soon be illegal to drive a diesel-powered Mercedes in parts of the city.
articles.abstract: A court ruling has shaken Stuttgart, where it may soon be illegal to drive a diesel-powered Mercedes in parts of the city.
articles.lead_paragraph: STUTTGART, Germany — The star of Daimler shines bright over Stuttgart. The giant illuminated emblem of its most famous car, the Mercedes, towers above the main train station, greeting visitors. It is visible for miles.

articles.headline: Jared Kushner’s Security Clearance Downgraded
articles.snippet: The president’s adviser and son-in-law lost his top-secret clearance, a White House official and another person familiar with Mr. Kushner’s situation said.
articles.abstract: The president’s adviser and son-in-law lost his top-secret clearance, a White House official and another person familiar with Mr. Kushner’s situation said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Jared Kushner, the president’s son-in-law and senior adviser, has been stripped of his top-secret security clearance after months of delays in completing his background check, and will now be limited in his ability to view highly classified information, a White House official and another person familiar with Mr. Kushner’s situation said on Tuesday.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Katie Rogers

articles.headline: In N.R.A. Fight, Delta Finds There Is No Neutral Ground
articles.snippet: A conservative backlash highlighted the challenge confronting corporations that are struggling to cater to both ends of America’s political and cultural poles.
articles.abstract: A conservative backlash highlighted the challenge confronting corporations that are struggling to cater to both ends of America’s political and cultural poles.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Delta Air Lines, one of Georgia’s largest private-sector employers, is among the glossiest corporate jewels in the state, contributing billions of dollars a year to the economy. Its hundreds of daily flights in and out of Atlanta’s airport are the main reason Georgia’s capital can brag, with justification, that it is a truly international city.
articles.byline: By Richard Fausset and Tiffany Hsu

articles.headline: As Xi Tightens His Grip on China, U.S. Sees Conflict Ahead
articles.snippet: Whether it is saber-rattling in the South China Sea, proselytizing on American campuses or censorship of the web, China has alienated one constituency after another.
articles.abstract: Whether it is saber-rattling in the South China Sea, proselytizing on American campuses or censorship of the web, China has alienated one constituency after another.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A few weeks after Stephen K. Bannon left the White House in August, he was invited to a dinner at the Council on Foreign Relations to discuss American policy toward China. With his unbridled China bashing and dark talk of a looming conflict in the Pacific, Mr. Bannon expected to be roughed up by the group, which included China scholars, writers and veterans from past Republican and Democratic administrations.

articles.headline: Flying Taxis May Be Years Away, but the Groundwork Is Accelerating
articles.snippet: As in the early days of self-driving cars, companies are digging in now so they aren’t left behind later. Just don’t call the aircraft “flying cars.”
articles.abstract: As in the early days of self-driving cars, companies are digging in now so they aren’t left behind later. Just don’t call the aircraft “flying cars.”
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Flying cars are just starting to inch their way out of science fiction. But that is not stopping some companies from planning for flying taxi services.

articles.headline: Scared but Resilient, Stoneman Douglas Students Return to Class
articles.snippet: Her bloodstained shoes were taken away as evidence. Her backpack has a bullet hole in it. On Wednesday, Brooke Harrison returned to the school where she saw her classmates die.
articles.abstract: Her bloodstained shoes were taken away as evidence. Her backpack has a bullet hole in it. On Wednesday, Brooke Harrison returned to the school where she saw her classmates die.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARKLAND, Fla. — Brooke Harrison, 14, was still in a deep sleep when her mother knocked on her door and hugged her awake at 6:45 Wednesday morning. “You need to get up,” she told her daughter. “You don’t want to be late for school today.”

articles.headline: Trump Calls Sessions’s Handling of Surveillance Abuse Allegations ‘Disgraceful’
articles.snippet: The president scolded Jeff Sessions after he suggested that the Justice Department’s inspector general would look into accusations of surveillance abuses.
articles.abstract: The president scolded Jeff Sessions after he suggested that the Justice Department’s inspector general would look into accusations of surveillance abuses.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The long-simmering friction between President Trump and Attorney General Jeff Sessions erupted into an extraordinary public face-off on Wednesday as the investigation into Russia’s election interference roiled the administration and raised new questions about the independence of law enforcement agencies.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Katie Benner
